note.p: Thomas Jesse Wharton was attorney general of Mississippi during the Civil War and a circuit judge after Reconstruction.

Born on May 18, 1817, in Nashville, Tennessee, Wharton was a good student and graduated from Nashville law school at the age of 19. He moved to Clinton, Mississippi, in 1836 to practice law, but returned to Tennessee the following year, where he married Mary Edgar. The couple had nine children.

Around 1839 Wharton and his wife moved to Raymond, Mississippi. In 1856, he was appointed the state’s attorney general and his family moved to Jackson. He remained in that position for eight years, including during most of the Civil War. During the secession crisis of 1861, Wharton also served as a commissioner to Tennessee, tasked with encouraging his native state to secede and join the Confederacy.

After the Civil War, Wharton returned to law practice. In 1882, after Reconstruction, he was selected judge of the Seventh Judicial District. He held that position until 1886. Wharton died on January 28, 1900. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.

note.p: Charles Clark served as Mississippi’s governor during the last two years of the Civil War. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, on May 24, 1811, Clark later moved to Mississippi, where he became a lawyer and a state representative in the late 1830s. After successfully representing a Mississippi settler in a land dispute with members of the Choctaw Nation in the early 1840s, Clark received a large tract of land near Beulah, Mississippi, as payment. Clark eventually enlarged his property to over five thousand acres, making it one of the largest and most successful plantations in Mississippi. During this time, he married Ann Eliza Darden and between 1840 and 1852 fathered three children.

Clark volunteered for military service during the Mexican-American War in 1846 and raised a company of volunteers that was placed into the 2nd Mississippi Regiment. After its original commander resigned, Clark was elected colonel. Following the war in 1848, he returned to Mississippi resumed an interest in politics. He was selected as a delegate to a state convention in 1851 that debated the matter of secession in the wake of the Compromise of 1850, which had tried to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. Clark attended the convention as a Unionist, opposed to withdrawing from the Union. Developments over the next ten years changed his mind.

Clark won a seat in the Mississippi’s House of Representatives as a Whig, serving from 1856 to 1861. Following Abraham Lincoln’s election as president in 1860, Clark embraced Mississippi’s secession. When the Civil War broke out, Clark received a commission as a brigadier general in the Mississippi Militia. He later entered the Confederate Army and eventually took command of a division. Slightly wounded at the Battle of Shiloh in April 1862, he was more seriously wounded and captured during fighting at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in August 1862. Clark spent a short time as a prisoner of war before he was paroled by Union forces.

In 1863, Clark ran for governor of Mississippi, in the wake of Confederate defeats at Vicksburg and Jackson. Clark campaigned on continued resistance to the Union and easily won the executive seat. Due to Union campaigns in Mississippi, Clark periodically moved the state government, from Jackson to Macon, then to Columbus, and back to Macon. When Confederate forces in Mississippi surrendered in May 1865, Clark instructed the state legislature to convene for a special session in Jackson. In June 1865, federal troops at Jackson arrested Clark and imprisoned him at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.

Eventually released from federal custody, Clark returned to Bolivar County, Mississippi. He quietly practiced law and served on the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees during Reconstruction. In 1876, Clark received an appointment as chancellor for the fourth judicial district. He died a year later, on December 17, 1877. Clark is buried in a family cemetery at Beulah, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Charles Clark: Twenty-fourth Governor of Mississippi: 1863–1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

gloss.p: Taxation is "the process by which the government of a country obtains money from its people in order to pay for its expenses." (Cambridge Dictionary) During the American Civil War and Reconstruction, the U.S. and Confederate governments expanded their taxation systems to fund their government operations, including military; likewise, states levied their own taxes to fund their respective state governments, including Mississippi. References to Mississippi state taxes and Mississippi residents paying federal taxes are found within this subject tag.

On July 1, 1862, U.S. Congress passed the progressive Internal Revenue Act, and in 1863, the Confederacy likewise authorized a graduated federal income tax that exempted wages up to $1,000, levied a 1% tax on the first $1,500 over the exemption, and 2% on all additional income. Confederate tax systems were even more complicated than the Union's, as states operating under war-time reconstruction governments paid U.S. federal taxes. Income taxes supplemented an already robust tax system that included federal duties, stamp taxes, and fees, among others. Civil War taxes were not immediately repealed at the end of the war but continued until 1872, when President Ulysses Grant's administration sponsored the repeal of most of the "emergency" taxes. (Cynthia G. Fox, "Income Tax Records of the Civil War Years," 18, no. 4 (1986), Genealogy Notes, National Archives)

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Mississippi Legislation Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi (1857) was passed by the state legislature to revise the state laws to be executed in 1857. Special commissioners William L Sharkey, Henry T. Ellett, and Samuel S. Boyd, who later resigned and was replaced by William L. Harris, were appointed on March 1, 1854, to oversee changes to current laws, and to make amendments, create new laws, or remove outdated statutes from the Mississippi law books. These amendments were produced for the legislature where they were further scrutinized and amended, finally passing after three years of adjudication. (The Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi, 1857)
"A time when people vote in order to choose someone for a political or official job." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The United States Constitution was ratified in 1788 as the foundational code of laws for the United States of America. It was crafted in 1787 by a convention in Philadelphia originally tasked only with amending the existing Articles of Confederation, which had loosely combined the states under a weak central government. Delegates chose to set aside the articles entirely and create a stronger federal government made of three branches: the legislative (comprising two separate parts, the House of Representatives and the Senate), the judicial (led by the Supreme Court), and the executive (headed by the President of the United States). The Constitution sought to carefully balance competing interests regarding state and national authority, as well as large and small state representation. It also created a more direct relationship between Americans and the national government.

The convention’s departure from its original mandate to amend the Articles of Confederation generated controversy, particularly among Americans who opposed placing a distant central authority of the states. The Constitution’s supporters advocated the need for a stronger national government and explained that the federal system preserved state authority for most local matters. To guarantee enough support for ratification, the Constitution’s supporters agreed to add an addendum to more directly protect individuals' specific rights and freedoms. The Constitution was ratified in 1788 and the new United States government began in early 1789. Shortly afterwards, the new Congress adopted several amendments to the Constitution, ten of which were ratified by three-fourths of the states and became known as the Bill of Rights. These first ten amendments guaranteed certain rights for American citizens. Since then, seventeen additional amendments have been ratified to the United States Constitution. Three of them—the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments—were adopted between 1865 and 1870, during the Reconstruction Era. The Thirteenth Amendment formally abolished slavery. The Fourteenth Amendment provides equal protection for all laws and the Fifteenth Amendment protects voting rights for American citizens regardless of “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” both specifically to combat racial discrimination against African Americans following the end of slavery. (Wikipedia; National Archives and Records Administration)

Operating at the state level, the Attorney General Office of Mississippi is located in Jackson, Mississippi and was created in 1817 by the Constitution of Mississippi. The Attorney General was a legislatively-elected position with a one-year term until 1832 when the office become popularly-elective and the term was extended. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Treasurer's office was created in 1817 in Jackson when the state was admitted to the Union. The State Legislature appointed the State Treasurer until 1832 when the Treasurer became popularly elected to serve a two-year term (changed to four years in 1869). The State Treasurer is responsible for overseeing and maintaining Mississippi's financial records. (Wikipedia)

In the nineteenth-century United States, the diagnosis and treatment of mental illnesses advanced dramatically, though by 1900 it certainly still had far to go. In colonial America, mental illnesses were largely perceived as acts of God and thus inescapable and incurable. American society therefore dealt with people suffering from mental illnesses primarily through charitable organizations or benevolent societies like churches or almshouses.

Throughout the nineteenth century, however, as the ideals of the Enlightenment continued to evolve, Americans developed a more institutional, scientific approach to understanding and treating mental illnesses as curable and in turn developing the field of psychiatry. Psychiatrists and state governments founded state-funded asylums to study and treat people with mental illnesses in isolation to prevent both interruption of treatment and danger to society. While nineteenth-century psychiatrists employed many terms no longer accepted to describe mental illnesses, and while the methods they employed in their asylums have likewise been largely dismissed, the study and treatment of mental illness in the United States advanced rapidly in the nineteenth century in tandem with greater societal and educational reforms.

It is critical to note, however, that much of this advancement was aided by slavery. The Eastern Lunatic Asylum of Virginia, for example, relied on enslaved people as both patients and caregivers, and ideas about blackness and insanity were often mutually dependent. (Wendy Gonaver, The Peculiar Institution and the Making of Modern Psychiatry, 1840–1880).

One notable, and widespread, mental illness afflicting Americans in the late nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries was the Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) experienced by many Civil War veterans. While psychiatry had evolved over the century, its failure to diagnose and treat widespread PTSD glaringly reveals its limits (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 283-285).

People with disabilities are defined as those people experiencing "any condition that makes it more difficult for a person to do certain activities or have equitable access within a given society" (Wikipedia). People with disabilities in nineteenth-century America faced a variety of different options and experiences based on both their region, age, and specific disability.

Early in the nineteenth century, many communities saw supporting people with disabilities as a local matter; however, as the nineteenth century progressed and cities and their populations (including people with disabilities) grew exponentially, many state governments took responsibility for supporting people with disabilities. That support most often took the form of almshouses or hospitals in which residents lived permanently, usually in rural areas for fear of urban environments' negative impacts on health. Different religious, medical, and reform organizations took different approaches to the treatment of disabilities, including the treatment of a person's morals in addition to medical care. Like many other branches of medicine, popular medical understandings of many disabilities remained incorrect and even harmful in the nineteenth century, particularly the concept of eugenics, or the idea that controlling genetics could improve or even perfect humanity. Doctors espousing these beliefs sometimes conducted forced sterilizations and lobotomies on their patients, either to prevent their reproduction or to reduce mental health issues.

The devastation of the American Civil War and the increase of people with war-related disabilities brought much more attention to the study of disabilities and their treatment, but ultimately humane and ethical methods of caring for people with disabilities remained far in the future. CWRGM adopts the term "People with disabilities" to foreground individuals' personhood over their status or physical condition (National Park Service; Wikipedia).

div.p: [seal]

Attorney General Office
Jackson, Novr. 14th 1864
His Exy Char Clark,

Governor,
Yr. fav. of the 9th. inst. by rea-son of delay of mails did not reach me until Saturday night. I despond at the earliest man out after having examined the questions submitted.

You inform me that many Sherriffs in the State, who were reelected at the special elections last month now in de-fault in payment of taxes due to the State. that such default existed prior to their reelection, and you inquire of me—
1st. Can commissions issued to the parties when the parities is known to you that they were in default at the time of election—
2nd Are the votes given for these Parties to be counted, or all not the parties, next present on the poll to the commission—
3. Should a new election be ordered by the Prest. Bd. Police, or in case of his vacancy, &ifso, before 1st Jany—
4. In case of new elections & no man elected do the parties hold on after the 1st Jany.
5. When Shff acted as returning officer and is reelected, does this [initiate?] his election—Can he be commisioned on his own return
6th When a party, other than the Sheriff held the election can he be commisioned on his own return, if elected Sheriff, or have other office—

You call my attention in considering the questions propounded, to the later clause of Art.112 Page 20 of the Code, which is as follows, "No person shall be eligible to the office of Sheriff who shall have held the office for the two next proceding terms; & who shall at the time of the election Is a defaulter to the State, or any County thereof, & to the United States"—

So much of said clause as many Sheriffs ineligable after two terms is repealed by act of Nov. 23. 1861— See acts 1861 p 84—There is much other legislation upon the subject, & the mbrs of construction require that all, in Pari Materia,be consid—ered together. The law has prescribed the time within which Sher-iffs or tax collectors shall pay into the State Treasury taxes collected— & the penalty for failure to comply. It imposes thirty per cent dam-ages, which may be unitted, or certificates of the Governor & Attorney General that the delay was not willful or avoidable—The Auditor is, moreover, required to notify the District Attorney, of the proper district, of the failure, & to furnish him a statement of the amt due, & the Dist. Atto. shall for^th^with institute Code p 85 Arts. 59—60—He is also required to within thirty days after the time when the returning of taxes are to be made to his office, to furnish the Governor a list of all in default, with the amount of taxes due for each, & the Governor may, therefore, upon such defaultry for office, & notify the Board Police on Code 72—Art 8—who may appoint a collector, until the vacancy is filled—It is also provided that if any State or County officer shall be found by inquest to be an idiot, lunatic &c during the period for which he is elected, or be found guilty of felony, or any infa-mous crime, corruption, or predations in office, or shall be re-moved from office by the Senator of any County of competent jurisdic-tion, the office held by him shall be thereof vacated &c—
Code page 95. Art. 24—
It is further provided that if any public officer in this State shall be convicted, on any indictment for malconduct as misdemeanor in office, the County mayshall, in addition to such

other punishment as may be punished, adjudge that the defendant be removed from office, & the office of such person shall be therof rendered vacant—Code p 138 Art 198— the whole scope of legislation, considered in the light of the Constitution which secures the right of trial by jury, and declares that no man shall be deprived of life, liberty or property but by due course of law, leads me to the conclu-sion that the summary power of removal from office by the Governor in the cases refered ^to^ upon the simple report of the auditor that they had failed to pay over the taxes within the time required by law, does not exist.

Consider by itself the clause quoted for Art 8 p 72— would seem to rest in the Governor a discretionary power of rem-oval. It is certainly qualified by the other papers I have gatherd. Standing alone, It would be repayment to the enlightened and liberal principles of the Constitution, to which I have referd to above. This consideration would incline me, if the doubt existing, or growing out of the legislation when the sub-ject was not as strong as it is, to the opinion, that only the fact when ascertained by judicial decision that the Sheriff was a defaulter could oust him of his office. A man has an estate, or property in an office for the law for which he was elected. I think he must be deprived of it—just as of any other property—by due course of law—

When ever that, by Arts. 59—60, page 85— of the same Chapter, the the Governer & Atto. Genl. may remit the damages imposed by law for a failure to settle with the Auditor within the time required, when they are satisfied that the delay was not affected.

and when not they remitted, although they are specif-ic, and are entered up by the Auditor, they can only be collected by suit or the bond of the Collector against myself and security. Now this last Statute must certainly be construed as a limitation or modifica-tion of the first—for if the damages can be re-mitted then there is no pretense to any that the Governor may at once forward to remove them from office, when the Auditor sends you his report. Who determines the fact of disqualification? I main-tain that it can only be determined in a direct pro-ceeding against the Sheriff before a Court of competent jurisdiction.

The Statute against dwelling disfranchising all per-sons concerned—principals, seconds, surgeons?, advising &c & declare that they shall be incapable of holding or being elected to any part of power, prospect &c under the Constitu-tion and laws of this State, & their appointment to any office, & all votes given to any such Juror for any office are de-clared illegal, and that no such votes shall be taken or Counted—Yit the fact that the party was concerned in a [duel?] must be judicially acertained.
It cannot be aproved by the Sheriff heading the election that he had been so engaged, and all votes polled for him be rejected.

So here. Although the law imposes that he cant [?]—[?] for failure to pay over taxes within the time pre—scirbed, & makes it the imperative duty of the Auditor to write them up, no exceptionscan infere against the de-faulting Sheriff. Why, for the reason that it is not an judicial decision.

For these reasons, I do not think you can aford to issue commissions, on the ground that the persons elec-ted to the offices are known to you to be defaultory: unless the fact be made known to you by sentences of a court of competent jurisdictions.
This view of the 1st makes it unnecessry to consider the 2d. 3d. and 4th interrogations proposed by you In answer to the 5th I remark, that the law has provided that when the Sheriff is a candidate,

or shall not attend the election he shall sum-mon the Coroner, or some justice of the peace of the County, who shall act as witnessing officer, & shall appoint deputies for the several precincts, & perform all the duties enjoined by law upon the Sheriff: Code page 91—Art. 4—It is further pro-vided by Art. 13—that the returning officers of the several precincts shall within two days after the vote shall have been counted, deliver to the return–ing officer of the County, a statement of the whole number of votes given for each person, & shall, within ten days after the day of said election, deliver a certif-icate of his election to the Juror having the ^[?]greatest number of votes, &c.

Your question does not suggest whether the Sheriff relected had Candidatcy—that is the candition expressed in the Statute. If they were not, they had the right, and it was their duty to act as returning officers. A person may be elected to, without being a Candidate for an office. The Statute has not said that even when he is a candidate, acting as returning officer would [initiate?] the election, if he should be re elected. It has forbidden him so to act, & has said who shall be appointed, but is silent as to the effect of a fail-ure to present the Statute. Inclined to think in such ^case^ ever. (I mean where he was a Candidate—acted as returning officer, & was re elected) The election would be voidable only. I think the Statute is directory as to the mode &c. This will suply an answer to your 6th which supposes the care of another than the Sheriff holding the election—within he can be commissioned on his own return, if elected Sheriff, or to any other office That is a case entirely outside of the Statute—is a [causes?][omi?]—[sus?]. I do not think, for any reason Stated in the interrogatory, you could aford to issue the com-mission.

I am, Governor,
Your Obt Sev't
